citations.narrative:
According to the facility, one ostrich was killed, and one ostrich was mortally wounded by the facility’s spotted hyena. The
second ostrich was euthanized due to the severity of the wounds. The ostriches were housed in the large outdoor
hoofstock enclosure that shared an enclosure fence line with the spotted hyena. A facility representative stated that the
hyena was able to contact and kill/wound the ostriches. The facility has begun to build a separate fence line for the
hoofstock enclosure that is sufficient distance from the hyena enclosure fence, but it has not been completed. Failure to
provide a safe primary enclosure can result in injury and/or death of the birds contained within. Housing facilities for birds
must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from entering that may negatively
affect the welfare of the birds within. To be corrected by April 11, 2025.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A young goat housed in a room with a wallaby, armadillos, a ferret, and muntjacs was observed to have hair loss. The
fairly symmetrical hairless patch was on the back of the goat, just behind the neck, and extended half-way down the side
of the chest. The patch extended approximately 4 inches along the spine of the goat, and approximately 3 inches down
the side of the chest on each side. When pointed out to the facility representative, they stated that they thought it was
probably due to the wallaby. The attending veterinarian was contacted, and they stated that they were not aware of the
issue.
Additionally, a male crab-eating macaque was identified as having a fresh wound on the tail. Approximately 2 inches of
the tip of the tail was bright red, and missing hair and flesh. The facility representative stated that they believed the wound
to have occurred within the last 12-24 hours, had treated it with wound care, and had notified the attending veterinarian.
They stated that the attending veterinarian had plans to visit the facility and look at the animal that day. The attending
veterinarian was contacted, and they stated that they were not aware of the condition of the macaque, and the last they
had spoken with the licensee was two days prior.
Inadequate daily observations and/or lack of timely communication with the attending veterinarian concerning any animal
health issues observed by the licensee may result in animal discomfort or pain and suffering due to a lack of veterinary
evaluation. The facility must perform daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being and maintain a
mechanism of direct and frequent communication so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health,
behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. To be corrected by April 7, 2025.

At the beginning of the inspection, the facility’s lobby was entered by inspectors about 30 minutes following opening for
the day. The front door to the lobby was wide open, along with the door on the other side of the lobby leading to the
outdoor animal enclosures. There was no facility representative or attendant inside. In the lobby, there was a cotton-
topped tamarin on display in a wired cage with a sign that stated, “We bite! Please don’t touch. Thank you.” There were
no public barriers around the cage housing the primate to prevent members of the public from contacting the animal.
About 5 minutes after waiting in the lobby, a facility employee entered and then immediately left to fetch another facility
representative. The next facility representative did not appear for another 5 minutes. Failure to provide adequate public
barriers can result in inappropriate interactions between the animal and the public, and result in possible injury or harm to
the public or animals. The facility must provide sufficient distance and/or barriers between animals and the general
viewing public during public exhibition to assure the safety of animals and the public. To be corrected by April 11, 2025.

In the large outdoor hoofstock enclosure housing sika deer, blackbuck, fallow deer, goats, and sheep, there are loose and
exposed electrical wires. A facility representative stated that the electrical company came to house the wires but left it
uncompleted. The loose wires extend beyond a vertical tube and are hanging down in a manner where they are easily
accessible by the animals. The facility representative stated the electrical company told them they could not do anything
with the wires, but nothing has been done to prevent animals from being able to reach the area. Exposed wires accessible
to hoofstock could lead to injury or harm to the animal, by way of ingestion or by electric shock if live. The outdoor housing
facilities shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. To be corrected by April 11, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. The exit interview was conducted via phone with the
licensee on March 28, 2025.
Additional Inspectors:
BEVERLY HICKS, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
3.150(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
According to the facility, one ostrich was killed, and one ostrich was mortally wounded by the facility’s spotted hyena. The

affect the welfare of the birds within. To be corrected by April 11, 2025. 
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A young goat housed in a room with a wallaby, armadillos, a ferret, and muntjacs was observed to have hair loss. The

Inadequate daily observations and/or lack of timely communication with the attending veterinarian concerning any animal

behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. To be corrected by April 7, 2025.

2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
At the beginning of the inspection, the facility’s lobby was entered by inspectors about 30 minutes following opening for 
the day. The front door to the lobby was wide open, along with the door on the other side of the lobby leading to the 
outdoor animal enclosures. There was no facility representative or attendant inside. In the lobby, there was a cotton-

About 5 minutes after waiting in the lobby, a facility employee entered and then immediately left to fetch another facility

barriers can result in inappropriate interactions between the animal and the public, and result in possible injury or harm to 
the public or animals. The facility must provide sufficient distance and/or barriers between animals and the general 
viewing public during public exhibition to assure the safety of animals and the public. To be corrected by April 11, 2025. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
In the large outdoor hoofstock enclosure housing sika deer, blackbuck, fallow deer, goats, and sheep, there are loose and 
exposed electrical wires. A facility representative stated that the electrical company came to house the wires but left it 
uncompleted. The loose wires extend beyond a vertical tube and are hanging down in a manner where they are easily

facilities shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. To be corrected by April 11, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. The exit interview was conducted via phone with the 
licensee on March 28, 2025. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
BEVERLY HICKS, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
